revision.text:
'''Aphelia''' (Greek, "plainness") is a rhetorical term that refers to the plainness of writing or speech.<ref>Lanham, Richard A. ''A Handlist of Rhetorical Terms''. 2nd ed. Berkeley: University of California Press, 1991. 17. Print.</ref> It is used to explain or teach rather than to entertain or elicit an emotional response.<ref>Zimmerman, Brett. "A Catalogue of Rhetorical and Other Literary Terms from American Literature and Oratory." ''Style'' 22 Dec. 1997: n. pag. Web. 29 Sep. 2013.</ref>
==Style== The sentence structure is typically both short in length and lacks "poetic and rhetorical adornment." <ref>Zimmerman, Brett. ''Edgar Allan Poe: Rhetoric and Style''. Montreal: McGill-Queen's University Press, 2005. 139. Print.</ref> [[Parataxis]] and [[asyndeton]] are also expected within the plain style. Writing or speech using aphelia may display a "right-branching" sentence structure for the most part; that is, the sentence will begin with an [[independent clause]] that will be followed by at least one [[dependent clause]].<ref>Zimmerman, Brett. ''Edgar Allan Poe: Rhetoric and Style''. Montreal: McGill-Queen's University Press, 2005. 138. Print</ref>
==Examples== *"In plain prose, here are four whales as well known to the students of Cetacean History as Marius or Sylla to the classic scholar." — [[Herman Melville]], [[Moby-Dick]] *"I knew what the old man felt, and pitied him, but chuckled at heart." — [[Edgar Allan Poe]], [[The Tell-Tale Heart]] *"She presented all of the ordinary appearances of death. The face assumed the usual pinched and sunken outline. The lips were of usual marble pallor. The eyes were lustreless. There was no warmth. Pulsation had ceased." — [[Edgar Allan Poe]], [[The Premature Burial]]
==See also== *[[Rhetoric]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Rhetoric]]

revision.text:
In [[machine learning]], '''Bayesian Program Synthesis (BPS)''', Bayesian Programs write (synthesize) new Bayesian programs. This is in contrast to the field of [[Probabilistic programming language|probabilistic programs]] where humans write new probabilistic (Bayesian) programs.
[[Bayesian probability|Bayesian probabilities]] is a strategy to learn distributions over Bayesian programs.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.technologyreview.com/s/603542/ai-software-juggles-probabilities-to-learn-from-less-data/|title=AI Software Juggles Probabilities to Learn from Less Data|last=Knight|first=Will|date=|work=MIT Technology Review|access-date=2017-03-09|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en}}</ref>
Bayesian Program Synthesis can be compared to the work on Bayesian Program Learning by Lake, Salakhutdinov, and Tenenbaum's,<ref name=":1" /> where probabilistic program components were hand-written, pre-trained on data, and then hand assembled in order to recognize handwritten characters.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Lake|first=Brenden M.|last2=Salakhutdinov|first2=Ruslan|last3=Tenenbaum|first3=Joshua B.|date=2015-12-11|title=Human-level concept learning through probabilistic program induction|url=http://science.sciencemag.org/content/350/6266/1332|journal=Science|language=en|volume=350|issue=6266|pages=1332–1338|doi=10.1126/science.aab3050|issn=0036-8075|pmid=26659050}}</ref>
== The framework == Bayesian Program Synthesis (BPS) has been described as a framework related to and utilizing probabilistic programming. In BPS, probabilistic programs are generated that are themselves priors over a space of probabilistic programs.<ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/Technology/2017/0216/Startup-pairs-man-with-machine-to-crack-the-black-box-of-neural-networks|title=Startup pairs man with machine to crack the 'black box' of neural networks|last=Wood|first=Charlie|date=2017-02-16|work=Christian Science Monitor|access-date=2017-03-04|issn=0882-7729}}</ref> This strategy allows more automatic synthesis of new programs via inference and is achieved by the composition of modular component programs.
The modularity in BPS allows inference to work on and test smaller probabilistic programs before being integrated into a larger model.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://robohub.org/talking-machines-probabilistic-programming-with-ben-vigoda/|title=Talking Machines: Probabilistic programming, with Ben Vigoda {{!}} Robohub|website=robohub.org|language=en-US|access-date=2017-03-04}}</ref>
Bayesian methods and models are frequently used to incorporate prior knowledge. When good prior knowledge can be incorporated into a Bayesian model, effective inference can often be performed with much less data.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://www.wired.com/2017/02/ais-factions-get-feisty-really-theyre-team/|title=AI’s Factions Get Feisty. But Really, They’re All on the Same Team|last=Metz|first=Cade|work=WIRED|access-date=2017-03-04|language=en-US}}</ref>
This framework can be also be contrasted with the family of automated [[program synthesis]] fields, including program synthesis, [[programming by example]], and [[programming by demonstration]]. The goal in such fields is to find the best program that satisfies some constraint. In program synthesis, for instance, verification of logical constraints reduce the state space of possible programs, allowing more efficient search to find an optimal program. Bayesian Program Synthesis differs both in that the constraints are probabilistic and the output is itself a distribution over programs that can be further refined.<ref name=":0" />
== See also == * [[Probabilistic programming language|Probabilistic Programming Language]]
== References == {{reflist}}
== External links == * Commentary on BPS by [[David Garrity]]: [http://www.bnn.ca/video/artificial-intelligence-to-see-significant-progress-in-2017-gva~1082352 Artificial Intelligence to see Significant Progress in 2017]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Bayesian Probability}} [[Category:Bayesian statistics|Probability]] [[Category:Computer programming]] [[Category:Probability interpretations]] [[Category:Philosophy of mathematics]] [[Category:Philosophy of science]] [[Category:User interfaces]] [[Category:Programming paradigms]]

revision.text:
[[File:Beijing-Forestry-University-2009-Oct.jpg|thumb|right|400px|Beijing Forestry University, main entrance, October 2009]] '''Beijing Forestry University''' ('''BFU''', or '''BJFU''') ({{zh|c=北京林业大学}}) is a university in [[Haidian District, Beijing|Haidian District]], [[Beijing]] focusing on forestry.<ref>[http://www.bjfu.edu.cn/ Home]. Beijing Forestry University. Retrieved on 9 July 2018. "北京林业大学 地址：北京市海淀区清华东路35号"</ref>
It is an environmentally friendly university sharing knowledge of sciences, engineering, laws, arts and languages to the world. It is one of the [[Project 211]] universities (top 100 China's universities in the 21st century), and it provides a wide range of courses, such as [[Artificial Intelligence]], [[Automation]], [[Biology]], [[Computer science]], [[Economics]], [[Electronics]], [[Environmental Science]], [[Forestry]], [[Languages]], [[Laws]], [[Management]], [[Mathematics]], [[Physics]] and [[Psychology]], to students. To share its environmental friendly mind to the world, the university is now providing modern technologies for people to protect the earth.<ref name=bjfu-edu>{{cite web|title=Beijing Forestry University|url=http://www.bjfu.edu.cn/english/|publisher=bjfu.edu.cn|accessdate=26 February 2014}}</ref><ref name=forestry>{{cite web|title=Beijing Forestry University|url=http://en.csc.edu.cn/laihua/universitydetailen.aspx?collegeId=37|publisher=en.csc.edu.cn|accessdate=26 February 2014}}</ref><ref name=steptostudy>{{cite web|title=Beijing Forestry University|url=http://steptostudy.com/schools/public/presentare/showSchoolDetails.php?schoolId=2594|publisher=steptostudy.com|accessdate=26 February 2014}}</ref>
It was ranked 281 in Asia by the [[QS World University Rankings]]: Asia 2018.<ref name=qsrankingasia>{{cite web|title=QS World University Rankings: Asia 2018|url=https://www.topuniversities.com/university-rankings/asian-university-rankings/2018|publisher=www.topuniversities.com}}</ref> It is a Chinese Ministry of Education [[Double First Class University Plan|Double First Class Discipline University]], with Double First Class status in certain disciplines.<ref name="Chinese Department of Education">{{Cite web |url=http://www.moe.gov.cn/srcsite/A22/moe_843/201709/t20170921_314942.html |title=教育部 财政部 国家发展改革委 关于公布世界一流大学和一流学科建设高校及建设 学科名单的通知 (Notice from the Ministry of Education and other national government departments announcing the list of double first-class universities and disciplines)}}</ref>
== History == Beijing Forestry University was founded as the Forestry Department of the [[Imperial University of Peking]] in 1902. In 1952, it had become an institute and was renamed as Beijing Institute of Forestry. In 1985, it was renamed as Beijing Forestry University, and it started to focus on a wide range of new subjects, including [[Electronics]], [[Computer Science]], [[Psychology]], [[Economics]], etc. Now it has 14 schools providing more than 60 undergraduate taught programs, more than 120 postgraduate master programs and more than 40 Ph.D. programs to students.
== Schools == The university has 14 schools: * School of '''Art''' * School of '''Biological Sciences and Biotechnology''' * School of '''Economics and Management''' * School of '''Environmental Science and Engineering''' * School of '''Foreign Languages''' * School of '''Forestry''' * School of '''Humanities and Social Sciences''' * School of '''Information Science and Technology''' * School of '''Landscape Architecture''' * School of '''Material Science and Technology''' * School of '''Nature Conservation''' * School of '''Science''' * School of '''Soil and Water Conservation''' * School of '''Technology'''
== Faculty == Since its establishment over 50 years ago, more than 30,000 Chinese and a number of foreign students have graduated from Beijing Forestry University. Of that number, 11 have attained the position of [[academician]]. The university faculty consists of 956 full-time teachers, including five academicians and 496 full and associate professors. While upholding traditional disciplines, the university has also established a large number of new disciplines to meet society's needs. The university consists of 15 schools; the [[graduate school]], [[biological science]] and technology, [[landscape architecture]], [[forestry]], [[environmental science]] and engineering, [[soil and water conservation]], industry, [[information science]], [[material science and technology]], [[science]], [[Conservation movement|conservation]], economic management, [[humanities]] and [[social sciences]], [[foreign languages]], [[vocational training]] and [[continuing education]].
The university features a computer center, a computer network center, an educational center, an audio-visual teaching center, a biological center, a micro-technology center, a forest-organism center and a tree farm for teaching and research (the Jiu Feng National Forest Park). Attached to the university are the Foreign-Language Training Center of the State Forestry Administration, the Research Center of Soil Control Technology of Loess Plateau in China and the Training Center of Desertification Control of China. BFU is a well-equipped institution, featuring the Central Building of Teaching, a gymnasium, laboratories, and a high-speed campus network. A computerized checking system exists for library books, and also in the library building is the Imported Teaching Materials Center for forestry universities and colleges nationwide. Construction of a high-rise student apartment building and a new classroom building was completed in 2001.
In recent years, nearly 200 discoveries in scientific research received awards from national, provincial and ministerial authorities, and more than 20 achievements of teaching were rewarded by the national and municipal governments. BFU is engaged in international academic exchanges and cooperation with more than 150 universities and research institutions in over 20 countries, providing opportunities for contacts between China and the outside world in the fields of forestry and environmental studies.
BFU provides an atmosphere for teaching and learning, combining the acquisition of professional knowledge with an improvement of all-round abilities (with an emphasis on forging a rigorous, creative academic style). Systems of optional courses, subsidiary courses, course exemption, and bachelor-to-master continuing education have been established so students may develop according to their own interests and desires. The university also offers extracurricular activities to enrich campus life; these are organized by student societies and associations in fields including science and technology, art, sports, environmental protection, and politics. Some groups have become influential, including the Society of Scientific Exploration and Wilderness Survival and the Association of Beijing College Volunteers for Environmental Protection. The former received the Prize of the Earth, the top prize from the National Bureau of Environmental Protection. In recent years, BFU students of BFU won four consecutive prizes at the College Students' Landscape Gardening Architecture Design Competitions (sponsored by UNESCO and the International Association of Landscape Gardening Architects), the Golden Prize in International College Students' Architecture Design and prizes in garden-design competitions. Achievements were also earned in domestic competitions for scientific inventions, mathematics, and art.
==Notable people== Notable alumni include: *[[He Qiaonv]], founder of Beijing Orient Landscape, one of Asia's largest landscape architecture companies<ref name="forbes">{{cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/profile/he-qiaonv/|title=He Qiaonv - Forbes|work=Forbes}}</ref> *[[Cui Yuying]], Deputy Head of the [[Propaganda Department of the Communist Party of China]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== {{Portal|Beijing|University}} * [http://www.bjfu.edu.cn/ Official website] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20081110155149/http://bjfu.6dxy.com/ Campus real three-dimensional map]

revision.text:
A '''broadcast auxiliary service''' or '''BAS''' is any [[radio frequency]] system used by a [[radio station]] or [[TV station]], which is not part of its direct [[broadcasting|broadcast]] to listeners or viewers. These are essentially internal-use [[backhaul (telecom)|backhaul]] channels not intended for actual [[Television reception|reception]] by the public, but part of the [[airchain]] required to get those signals to such a [[transmitter (radio)|transmitter]]. Examples include: *[[studio/transmitter link]] (STL) *[[transmitter/studio link]] (TSL) *[[remote pickup unit]] (RPU) *[[electronic news gathering]] (ENG) Several of these bands exist, but the most frequently used band is the 2GHz [[microwave]] BAS band for point-to-point transmission from mobile newsgathering units to mountaintop receivers. Seven 12-MHz wide channels exist in the band. In North America, DVB-T. precisely the same modulation technique as European Broadcast, is used, using a constellation of QPSK, 16QAM, or 64QAM, enabling sufficient digital bandwidths at 6MHz deviation for transmission of an MPEG transport stream at 10 or more megabits per second, producing three "lower", "center", and "upper" overlapping 6MHz channels within each 12MHz channel. [[File:BAS-2018.png|center|frameless|800x800px|2GHz FCC Band Plan with 6MHz Subdivisions]] ==2GHz relocation== In the [[United States]] between 2005 and 2010, the [[Federal Communications Commission]] (FCC) moved [[TV channel]]s in the 2 GHz TV BAS band at the request of [[Sprint Nextel]], so that it could use a portion which was adjacent to [[personal communications services|PCS]] frequencies it already uses. The [[report and order]] resulting from this [[rulemaking]] specified that Sprint/Nextel must pay for every TV station using the band to buy and install new BAS equipment to work in the new band structure. Previously, there had been seven [[analog TV]] channels, each 17 or 18 MHz wide, between 1990 and 2110 MHz. The new allocation created seven [[digital TV]] channels, each 12 MHz wide, from 2025.5 to 2109.5 MHz. (There was also a "narrowed in place" [[bandplan]] used as an [[interim]] measure, as the two bands overlap.)
Begun in 2005, the relocation was 94% complete as of October 2008, and was expected to be fully complete in mid 2009. After multiple extensions granted by the FCC, it was finally done in July 2010, with the completion of the [[Anchorage]], [[Alaska]] [[TV market]]. The cleared band is now used for PCS, [[List of AWS-1 devices|AWS]], and [[mobile satellite service|MSS]] services, including [[mobile broadband]]. ==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20120321172616/http://broadcastengineering.com/eng/sprint-nextel-completes-2ghz-bas-relocation-20100728/ ''Broadcast Engineering'' article on completion] *[http://www.tvtechnology.com/article/bas-relocation-complete/206640/ ''TV Technology'' article on completion, with insider details] {{bcast-stub}} [[Category:Broadcast engineering]]

revision.text:
{{About|the human geography and sociological term|the geomorphological meaning|Drainage basin}} {{Refimprove|date=November 2008}}
In [[human geography]], a '''catchment area''' is the area from which a city, service or institution attracts a population that uses its services. For example, a school catchment area is the [[geographic]] area from which students are eligible to attend a local [[school]].
Governments and [[community service]] organizations often define catchment areas for planning purposes and [[public safety]] such as ensuring universal access to services like fire departments, police departments, ambulance bases and hospitals.
==Creation== Catchment areas are generally established and modified by local governments. These boundaries can be modeled using [[geographic information system]]s (GIS).<ref>{{cite journal |last1=McLafferty |first1=Sara L. |title=GIS and Health Care |journal=Annual Review of Public Health |volume=24 |issue= |pages=25–42 |year=2003 |pmid=12668754 |doi=10.1146/annurev.publhealth.24.012902.141012 }}</ref> There can be large variability in the services provided within different catchments in the same area depending upon how and when those catchments were established.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Jenkins |first1=C. |last2=Campbell |first2=J. |title=Catchment areas in general practice and their relation to size and quality of practice and deprivation: a descriptive study in one London borough |journal=BMJ |volume=313 |issue=7066 |pages=1189–92 |year=1996 |pmid=8916754 |pmc=2352502 |doi=10.1136/bmj.313.7066.1189 }}</ref> They are usually contiguous but can overlap when they describe competing services.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Schuurman |first1=Nadine |last2=Fiedler |first2=Robert S |last3=Grzybowski |first3=Stefan CW |last4=Grund |first4=Darrin |title=Defining rational hospital catchments for non-urban areas based on travel-time |journal=International Journal of Health Geographics |volume=5 |issue= |pages=43 |year=2006 |pmid=17018146 |pmc=1617091 |doi=10.1186/1476-072X-5-43 }}</ref>
===Defining=== Catchments can be defined based upon a number of factors including distance to the facility, actual travel time to the facility, geographic boundaries or population within the catchment. In a distance based catchment, the area serviced will often depend on the number of visits expected to that institution by each individual. For example, it may be more acceptable to have a larger catchment for a hospital where any one individual will have few annual visits in comparison to a school where visits will be daily and hence desired distance would be closer. When a facility’s capacity can only service a certain volume, the catchment may be used to limit a population’s ability to access services outside that area.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Parsons |first1=Eddie |last2=Chalkley |first2=Brian |last3=Jones |first3=Allan |title=School Catchments and Pupil Movements: A case study in parental choice |journal=Educational Studies |volume=26 |issue=1 |year=2000 |pages=33–48 |doi=10.1080/03055690097727 }}</ref> For example, children may be unable to enroll in a school outside their catchment to prevent the school's services being exceeded.
==Examples== *[[Airport]]s can be built and maintained in locations which minimize the driving distance for the surrounding population to reach them.<ref>{{cite web |title=Airports: Non-Financial Analysis |publisher=[[Transport Canada]] |url=http://www.tc.gc.ca/programs/airports/RSAS/nonfinanalysis.htm }}</ref> *A neighborhood or district of a city often has several small convenience shops, each with a catchment area of several streets. Supermarkets, on the other hand, have a much lower density, with catchment areas of several neighborhoods (or several villages in rural areas). This principle, similar to the [[central place theory]], makes catchment areas an important area of study for [[geographers]], [[economists]], and [[urban planners]]. *In Nigeria, most Federal Schools respect the fact that some states are educationally less developed than others. The country's higher education <ref>{{cite web |title=Admission: University Admission |publisher=Students Nigeria |url=https://www.students.com.ng/category/admission }}</ref> catchment areas have therefore been designed to ensure a good mixture of students from different backgrounds.
==See also== *[[Hinterland]] *[[School district]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * {{fr}} [http://www.owlapps.net/application-geomarketing/ http://www.owlapps.net/application-geomarketing: catchment area calculations free webapp ] * [https://www.students.com.ng/list-nigerian-universities-catchment-areas: List of Nigerian Universities Catchment Areas ]
[[Category:Human geography]] [[Category:Economic geography]]

revision.text:
{{Short description|A catenary arch is an architectural pointed arch that follows an inverted catenary curve}}
[[File:Catenaria in terra cruda a più corsi di conci.jpeg|400px|thumb|right|A [[mudbrick]] catenary arch]] [[File:Hanging chain and arch.svg|400px|thumb|right|A [[catenary curve]] (left) and a catenary arch, also a catenary curve (right). One points up, and one points down, but the curves are the same.]]
A '''catenary arch''' is a type of [[architecture|architectural]] [[pointed arch]] that follows an inverted [[catenary curve]]. It is common in [[cathedral]]s and in [[Gothic arch]]es used in [[Gothic architecture]].<ref name="American Scientist">{{cite web|url=https://www.americanscientist.org/issues/pub/2011/3/the-perfect-dome|title=Letter to the Editors: The Perfect Dome|author=Handy, Richard L.|date=May 2011|work=American Scientist}}</ref> It is not a [[parabolic arch]].
==In history== [[File:17 Robert Hooke Engineer.JPG|thumb|250px|right|alt=Painting of Robert Hooke seated in a study, holding a small chain suspended between his hands by the ends|[[Robert Hooke]], holding a hanging [[chain]], which forms a catenary curve]]
The 17th-century scientist [[Robert Hooke]] wrote, "''Ut pendet continuum flexile, sic stabit contiguum rigidum inversum''", or, "As hangs a flexible cable so, inverted, stand the touching pieces of an arch." <ref name="The enigma of Robert Hooke">{{cite web|url=https://quantumfrontiers.com/2015/08/31/the-enigma-of-robert-hooke/|title=The enigma of Robert Hooke|author=|date=31 August 2015|work=Quantum Frontiers|publisher=Institute for Quantum Information and Matter, California Institute of Technology}}</ref>
A note written by [[Thomas Jefferson]] in 1788 reads, "I have lately received from Italy a treatise on the equilibrium of arches, by the Abbé Mascheroni. It appears to be a very scientifical work. I have not yet had time to engage in it; but I find that the conclusions of his demonstrations are, that every part of the [[catenary]] is in perfect equilibrium".<ref>{{cite book|last1=Jefferson|first1=Thomas|title=Memoir, Correspondence, and Miscellanies, from the Papers of Thomas Jefferson, Volume 2|date=1830|publisher=Gray and Bowen|location=Boston|page=416|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Qjw-AAAAYAAJ&pg=PA416&lpg=PA416|language=en}}</ref>
==Structural properties== What makes the catenary arch important is its ability to withstand weight.<ref name="St. Louis Gateway Arch">{{cite web|url=http://www.enchantedlearning.com/history/us/monuments/stlouisarch/|title=St. Louis Gateway Arch|author=|date=|work=enchantedlearning.com|accessdate=27 April 2016}}</ref><ref name="strath.ac.uk">{{cite web|url=http://personal.strath.ac.uk/j.wood/Biomimetics/Engineering%20Areas/structures/PROP%201_files/PROP%201.htm|title=Building an arch that can stand up by itself|author=|date=|work=strath.ac.uk|accessdate=27 April 2016}}</ref> For an arch of uniform density and thickness, supporting only its own weight, the catenary is the ideal curve.<ref name="The inverted catenary arch">{{cite web|url=http://zonedome.com/?p=167|title=The inverted catenary arch|author=|date=|work=zonedome.com|accessdate=27 April 2016}}</ref>
This is done by a catenary curve: Catenary arches are strong, as they redirect the vertical force of gravity into compression forces pressing along the arch's curve. In a uniformly loaded catenary arch, the [[line of thrust]] runs through its center.<ref name="Build an arch that can stand up by itself">{{cite web|url=http://www.exploratorium.edu/files/cmp/exnet/exhibits/group1/catenary_arch/media/catenary_g.pdf|title=Build an arch that can stand up by itself|author=|date=|work=|accessdate=}}</ref><ref name="Getting the arch back into architecture">{{cite web|url=http://publications.lib.chalmers.se/records/fulltext/203465/203465.pdf|title=Getting the arch back into architecture|author=Karl Robin Nilsson|date=|work=|accessdate=}}</ref>
{{clear}}
==Examples==
===Cathedrals and churches=== [[File:St Paul's Cathedral's dome.jpg|225px|thumb|right|St Paul's Cathedral's dome]] * [[King’s College Chapel]], in [[Cambridge, England]]<ref name="The British Architect">{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=J60QAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA447&lpg=PA447&dq=catenary+arch+King%E2%80%99s+College+Chapel&source=bl&ots=AL329gQTAn&sig=2RJVDwaZLCsapd-ASAJcDvg84S4&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiN-puMm5LMAhXEzoMKHR6nAJ4Q6AEIQzAJ#v=onepage&q=catenary%20arch%20King%E2%80%99s%20College%20Chapel&f=false|title=The British Architect|author=|date=|work=google.com|accessdate=27 April 2016}}</ref> * [[St Paul's Dome]]<ref name="Maths in a minute: St Paul's dome">{{cite web|url=https://plus.maths.org/content/maths-minute-st-pauls-dome|title=Maths in a minute: St Paul's dome|author=|date=|work=maths.org|accessdate=27 April 2016}}</ref> * [[Brunelleschi's Dome]]<ref name="Brunelleschi's Dome">{{cite web|url=https://www.21stcenturysciencetech.com/Articles_2014/Brunelleschi.pdf|title=Brunelleschi's Dome|author=Nora Hamerman and Claudio Rossi|date=|work=|accessdate=}}</ref><ref name="http://schillerinstitute.org/educ/pedagogy/2013/vereycken-dome-1.html">The Secrets of the Florentine Dome: [http://schillerinstitute.org/educ/pedagogy/2013/vereycken-dome-1.html The Secrets of the Florentine Dome], accessdate: January 25, 2017</ref> * [[Casa Batlló]] has catenary arches<ref name="Casa Batlló">{{cite web|url=http://www.barcelonaturisme.com/wv3/en/page/748/.html|title=Casa Batlló|author=|date=|work=|accessdate=2 May 2016}}</ref> * [[Casa Mila]], in [[Barcelona, Spain]]<ref name="The Catenary Arch">{{cite web|url=http://naturalhomes.org/catenary.htm|title=The Catenary Arch|author=|date=|work=naturalhomes.org|accessdate=27 April 2016}}</ref> was designed by [[Antoni Gaudi]], who used many catenary arches<ref name="The Geometry of Antoni Gaudi">{{cite web|url=http://euler.slu.edu/escher/index.php/The_Geometry_of_Antoni_Gaudi|title=The Geometry of Antoni Gaudi|author=|date=|work=slu.edu|accessdate=27 April 2016}}</ref><ref name="Catenary Method">{{cite web|url=http://www.earth-auroville.com/maintenance/uploaded_pics/03-Stability-calculations.pdf|title=Catenary Method|author=|date=|work=|accessdate=}}</ref> * [[Church of Colònia Güell]]<ref name="Colònia Güell">{{cite web|url=http://www.barcelonaturisme.com/wv3/en/page/1275/colonia-guell.html|title=Colònia Güell|author=|date=|work=barcelonaturisme.com|accessdate=27 April 2016}}</ref>
===Natural arches=== [[File:LandscapeArchPano.jpg|220px|thumb|right|[[Landscape Arch]], [[Utah]]]]
[[Rainbow Natural Bridge]] in the U.S. state of [[Utah]] has a natural catenary shape, possibly produced by [[weathering]] in high-stress areas.<ref name="Arctic"/> [[Kolob Arch]] and [[Landscape Arch]], also in Utah, have a catenary shape as well.<ref name="The Dimensions of Kolob Arch">{{cite web|url=http://www.naturalarches.org/archinfo/kolob.htm|title=The Dimensions of Kolob Arch|author=Jay H. Wilbur|date=|work=|accessdate=}}</ref><ref name="Landscape Arch">{{cite web|url=https://www.geocaching.com/geocache/GC20EX7_landscape-arch?guid=24fcdaef-373c-47ab-92d0-3d3b42440f9f |title=Landscape Arch|author=Cincinnati Cache Collectors|date=|work=|accessdate=}}</ref>
===Human-made arches=== The [[Gateway Arch]] in the American city of [[St. Louis]] ([[Missouri]]) is an inverted catenary arch.<ref name="Modern Steel Construction">{{cite web|url=http://msc.aisc.org/globalassets/modern-steel/archives/1961-1995/1963v04.pdf|title=Modern Steel Construction|author=|date=|work=|accessdate=}}</ref>
Due to [[aspect ratio]], the top being thinner than the bottom, its actual shape is technically a "[[weighted catenary]]".<ref name="How the Gateway arch got its Shape">{{cite web|url=http://www.msri.org/people/staff/osserman/papers/NNJ_v12n2_Osserman_pp167-189.pdf|title=How the Gateway arch got its Shape|author=Robert Osserman |date=|work=|accessdate=}}</ref>
===High-rises=== [[File:Marquette Plaza.jpg|220px|thumb|right|[[Marquette Plaza]] in [[Minneapolis]]]] [[Marquette Plaza]] in [[Minneapolis]] used catenary arches.<ref name="Marquette Plaza Property Information">{{cite web|url=http://marquetteplaza.com/property|title=Marquette Plaza Property Information|author=|date=|work=|accessdate=2 May 2016}}</ref><ref name="Platinum Plaza">{{cite web|url=http://marquetteplaza.com/wp-content/uploads/2010/04/MP-Onesheets_FINAL.pdf|title=Platinum Plaza|author=|date=2 May 2016|work=|accessdate=2 May 2016}}</ref>
===Kilns=== [[Kiln]]s are often designed with catenary arch [[Cross section (geometry)|cross-section]].<ref name="Pottery Karematsu">{{cite web|url=http://www.potterykarematsu.com/kiln-building.html |title=Kiln Building |author=Ken Nagakui|date=1926|work=|accessdate=30 April 2016}}</ref>
===Igloos=== {{further|Igloo#Engineering}}
[[Igloos]] are designed with a catenary arch cross-section.<ref name="What house-builders can learn from igloos">{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/magazine/7326031.stm|title=What house-builders can learn from igloos |author=Dan Cruickshank|work=|accessdate=1 May 2016}}</ref><ref name="Arctic"/> This shape offers an optimal balance between height and diameter, avoiding the risk of collapsing under the weight of compacted snow.<ref name="Arctic">{{cite journal|last1=Handy|first1=Richard L.|title=The Igloo and the Natural Bridge as Ultimate Structures|journal=Arctic|date=Dec 1973|volume=26|issue=4|pages=276–281|url=http://pubs.aina.ucalgary.ca/arctic/Arctic26-4-276.pdf|publisher=Arctic Institute of North America|format=PDF|doi=10.14430/arctic2926}}</ref>
===Ancient Egyptians=== [[File:Saqqara ostracon.jpg|thumb|left|[[Saqqara ostracon]]]]
The unfinished [[Saqqara ostracon]] has a catenary shape.<ref name="Saqqara ostracon">{{cite web|url=http://www.egyptorigins.org/catenarycurve.htm|title=An Ancient Egyptian Catenary Construction Curve|author=|date=1926|work=|accessdate=}}</ref>
===Other architecture=== The inside of [[Budapest]]’s [[Keleti Railway Station]] forms a catenary arch.<ref name="Budapest">{{cite web|url=http://www.urbanrail.net/eu/hu/budapest/budapest.htm|title=Budapest|author=|date=|work=|accessdate=8 May 2016}}</ref>
The [[Nubian ton]] is a burial vault, of [[Nubia]], For greatest stability, the structure’s cross-section follows a catenary arch.<ref name="Nubian Ton">{{cite web|url=http://memim.com/catenary.html|title=Nubian Ton|author=|date=|work=|accessdate=}}</ref>
The [[beehive homes]] (clocháns) of Ireland’s [[Skellig Michael]] have a cross-section that follows the style of a catenary arch.<ref name="Beehive Homes">{{cite web|url=http://www.egyptorigins.org/catenarycurve.htm|title=Beehive Homes|author=|date=|work=|accessdate=}}</ref>
===Homes=== [[File:K borland-3.jpg|300px|thumb|right|[[Rice House, Eltham|Rice House]]]] The [[Rice House, Eltham|Rice House]] has catenary arches.<ref name="Rice House">{{cite web|url=http://vhd.heritage.vic.gov.au/reports/report_place/14272|title=Rice House|author=|date=|work=|accessdate=}}</ref>
===Hotels=== The [[Icehotel (Jukkasjärvi)|Icehotel]] in Sweden employs catenary arches.<ref name="Icehotel - facts">{{cite web|url=http://www.icehotel.com/about-icehotel/|title=Icehotel - facts|author=|date=|work=ICEHOTEL|accessdate=27 April 2016}}</ref>
===Bridges=== A [[catenary bridge]] has the form of a catenary arch.
One famous example is the [[An-Lan Bridge]], in [[China (nation)|China]].<ref name="Suspension Bridge">{{cite web|url=http://darkwing.uoregon.edu/~inaasim/Early%20China/Presentations/Adam%20-%20Bridges.htm|title=Suspension Bridge|author=|date=|work=uoregon.edu|accessdate=27 April 2016}}</ref>
===Monuments=== [[File:Ctesiphon, Iraq, 1932.jpg|300px|thumb|right|[[Taq Kasra]]]] In [[Iraq]], the [[Taq Kasra]] has the shape of a catenary arch.<ref name="Taq Kasra">{{cite web|url=http://people.bath.ac.uk/abscjkw/LectureNotes/what-is-a-shell.pdf|title=Taq Kasra|author=Chris J K Williams|date=|work=|accessdate=}}</ref>
===Airports=== The roof of [[Washington Dulles International Airport]] is a suspended catenary curve.<ref name="Dulles Airport">, {{cite web|url=http://architecture.about.com/od/findphotos/ig/Eero-Saarinen/Dulles-Airport-.htm|title=Dulles Airport|author=Jackie Craven|date=|work=|accessdate=}}</ref>
A catenary steel cable system supports the roof of [[Denver International Airport]].<ref name="Shell Structures">{{cite web|url=http://www.coloradomagazineonline.com/Travel/DIA_2010/DIA_2010.htm|title=Denver International Airport|author=|date=|work=|accessdate=}}</ref>
[[File:Dingle beehive hut.JPG|300px|thumb|right|A [[beehive home]] (a clochan) on [[Dingle Peninsula]], [[Kerry, Ireland]]]]
===Train stations=== [[New York City]]’s [[Pennsylvania Station (New York City)|Pennsylvania Station]] has a roof in the form of a catenary arch.<ref name="Pennsylvania Station">{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/01/14/nyregion/penn-stations-5th-redesign-fails-to-charm-some-critics.html?_r=0|title=Penn Station’s 5th Redesign Fails to Charm Some Critics|author=David W. Dunlap|date=1926|work=|accessdate=}}</ref>
===Banks=== On the [[Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis]], the building has been remodeled, but still visible is the catenary arch suspending the original building.<ref name="100 Years of the Ninth District Fed - Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis">{{cite web|url=https://www.minneapolisfed.org/about/locations/minneapolis/100-years-of-the-ninth-district-fed|title=100 Years of the Ninth District Fed - Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis|author=|date=|work=minneapolisfed.org|accessdate=27 April 2016}}</ref>
===Mud huts=== [[Cameroon]]'s [[musgum mud huts]] have a catenary cross-section.<ref name="musgum earth architecture">{{cite web|url=http://www.designboom.com/architecture/musgum-earth-architecture/|title=musgum earth architecture|author=|date=|work=|accessdate=2 May 2016}}</ref><ref name="Architecture Addiction, The Official Blog of">{{cite web|url=http://blog.architectureaddiction.com/index.php/a/2010/02/21/|title=Architecture Addiction, The Official Blog of|author=Katy Purviance|date=|work=|accessdate=2 May 2016}}</ref><ref name="Masonry Design">{{cite web|url=http://masonrydesign.blogspot.com/2010/05/arch-designs-corbels-and-catenaries.html|title=Masonry Design|author=|date=11 May 2010|work=|accessdate=23 December 2016}}</ref>
==See also==
* [[Arch bridge]] * [[Catenary]] * [[Catenary bridge]] * [[Cathedral]] * [[Dome]] * [[Gothic arch]] * [[Lancet window]] * [[Mathematics and architecture]] * [[Parabolic arch]] * [[Simple suspension bridge]] * [[Steel catenary riser]] * [[Vault (architecture)]] * [[Weighted catenary]]
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==External links== * [http://archive.bridgesmathart.org/2008/bridges2008-47.pdf The use of the catenary arch in architecture] * [http://www.naturalarches.org/archinfo/taxonomy-buttress.htm Natural arches that are catenary arches] * [http://twistedphysics.typepad.com/cocktail_party_physics/2007/10/the-catenary-ta.html Twisted Physics reference] * [http://naturalhomes.org/catenary.htm Used in building] * [http://www.house-design-coffee.com/catenary-arch.html More on the catenary, used in arches] * [http://www.architectural-review.com/archive/the-history-of-architecture-in-eleven-arches/8673174.fullarticle A few catenary arches] * [https://programs.omsi.edu/professionals/products/catenary-arch An experiment] * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AYIQYZuQNMw A youtube, all about catenary arches] * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vqfVKsBkB1s A second youtube] * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fcuM7iE_M48 a youtube on building a catenary arch] * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0KFVuEyqHzQ Another youtube]
[[Category:Arches and vaults]] [[Category:Architectural history]] [[Category:Catholic architecture]]

{{Other uses}} {{distinguish|Center for Strategic Research}} {{Infobox Organization |name = Center for Strategic Studies |image = CenterforStrategicStudies.jpg |caption = |abbreviation = CSS |motto = |formation = 1997 |type = [[Think tank]] |headquarters = [[Pasteur Street]] |location = Tehran, Iran |leader_title = President |leader_name = [[Hesamodin Ashna]] | key_people = [[Ebrahim Hajiani]], [[Mohammad Fazeli]], [[Soleiman Pakseresht]] |budget = |website = [http://www.css.ir/ css.ir] }} '''Center for Strategic Studies''' ({{lang-fa|مرکز بررسی‌های استراتژیک}}) is an Iranian [[think tank]] on [[strategy]] issues. It is the research arm of the [[Iranian President]]'s office. The current head of organization is [[Hesamodin Ashna]].<ref>[https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2014-05-22/iran-s-hardliners-fall-into-line-backing-zarif-in-nuclear-talks Iran’s Hardliners Fall Into Line Backing Zarif in Nuclear Talks]</ref><ref>[http://www.ir.undp.org/content/iran/en/home/presscenter/articles/2016/02/21/oining-forces-to-save-iran-s-drying-wetlands.html Joining forces to save Iran’s drying wetlands]</ref><ref>[https://www.intelligenceonline.com/government-intelligence/2016/06/01/inter-army-cooperation-explored,108162195-ART Inter-army cooperation explored]</ref><ref>[http://www.agi.it/international/2016/01/26/news/exhibition_celebrates_italy_and_irans_archeological_work-454783/ Exhibition celebrates Italy and Iran's archeological work]</ref><ref>[https://iranwire.com/en/features/1727 Khamenei goes Ballistic over Missile Tests]</ref><ref>[http://iranprimer.usip.org/blog/2014/aug/12/irans-leaders-iraq-crisis-and-isis Iran's Leaders on Iraq Crisis and ISIS]</ref> It was established in 1997 as a counterpart of [[Center for Strategic Research]].
== Network for Public Policy Studies == The [[Network for Public Policy Studies]] was established by the Center in 2015 to advance the study of [[public policies]].<ref>{{cite web|title=شبکه شمس، تلاش دولت یازدهم برای پیوند زدن نخبگان و حوزه های تصمیم گیر است|url=http://www.president.ir/fa/84293|website=Official website of the President of the Islamic Republic of Iran|accessdate=21 June 2017}}</ref> [[Mohammad Fazeli]] is the general editor of the website.
==See also== * [[Hassan Rouhani]] * [[Mohammad Mousavi Khoeiniha]] * [[Saeed Hajjarian]]
==References== <references/>
==External links== * [http://www.css.ir/ Center for Strategic Studies]
